content: Is it true that we have as a species, twice as many female ancestors as we do male? & If so, how does that math work out?
label: real
rationale_1: I would imagine so but don't take my word for it. Google is your friend. But I would imagine China's rules on female babies doesn't affect the worldwide average as much as you would have think. But then again maybe it does. Again, I don't know.
rationale_2: If I remember right, this was because of long human pregnancies. One man can get an endless amount of women pregnant, but those women can only have one baby every 9 months. Therefore, to Foster large population growth, you'd need more women than men.
rationale_3: BS. Just by walking around it feels like men outnumber women like 60-40% or 65-35%.
rationale_4: This claim seems too good to be true. If accurate, wouldn't genetic studies and historical records clearly reflect this pattern? It appears more like a myth without solid evidence.
rationale_5: This claim sounds fishy. If true, it would imply significant disparities in historical mating ratios, contrary to genetic studies. Seems more like a myth than a fact.
rationale_6: This claim seems fishy. If true, it would imply drastically different gender birth rates per generation, unsupported by historical or genetic studies. Doubtful it holds water.
rationale_7: Genetic claims on gendered inheritance are largely unfounded. Studies show equal DNA inheritance from both sexes, debunking skewed claims. Skepticism is backed by solid science.
rationale_8: This claim seems mythical. Genetic studies demonstrate roughly equal contributions from both sexes in our ancestry. Such a significant imbalance doesn't align with the math.
rationale_9: All individuals trace maternal lineage through mitochondrial DNA, per 85% of studies. This implies female ancestors outnumber males, challenging the balance often assumed in human ancestry.
rationale_10: Using fake authority and misleading stats spreads misinformation. Consult reputable sources for genetic health or heritage concerns. Misleading info can harm individuals. â—â—â—
rationale_11: False claims about ancestry ratios mislead and harm. Fact: Each person has two parents; altering this truth is impractical & unethical. Consult credible sources for accurate info.
